block.p: Years ago, when I was writing freelance interviews for The New York Times, I was severely depressed when I read a very funny interview with Elaine May in the Arts & Leisure section. ''I can never top that one,'' I thought. The next week it was revealed that Elaine May had written her own interview under a pseudonym. Maybe that's the way to go. I was reminded of that when I read Ms. May's piercing interrogation of Alan Arkin on why there are no bagels on the set of her play ''Taller Than a Dwarf'' [''Creation, Without Bagels,'' April 2]. Why, indeed? It also reminded me of Federico Fellini's way with an interviewer (myself) in 1975. ''Ask me easy questions,'' he said. ''Ask me about ice cream.'' Actually, I would have asked him about the shortage of bagels in Rome, but the phone rang and he talked about ''Casanova'' instead.
The writer is the author of ''Eye on the World: Conversations With International Filmmakers'' (Silman-James Press).
